text:
I'm going to guess this question has been brought up before and maybe you have some links to some great talks on this kind of stuff but ...

I'm watching an Alan Kay talk and sometimes I can't help but wonder if maybe the reason everyone isn't use Smalltalk or Lisp or Haskell or some Visual programming Environment is not because they are all stupid but because those systems actually have other problems.

I can give the example of my experience of Lisp. I wrote some incredible macros that would sort data at compile time to be cache friendly but that also meant anyone who wanted to use my code had to understand my macros. Maybe that's not fair since to use anything you have to understand it but it just got me wondering, like I know I feel more productive in JavaScript (usually) than say C# but I think that's probably because I'm writing relatively small things that are all in my head. As soon as I was on a team I'd want a typed language since it would help spread the knowledge of how things work?

Smalltalk often mentions the entire environment is written in smalltalk and modifiable live. That sounds great for experimenting but horrible for every day use. Imaging running `stpm` (smalltalk package manager) and having no idea how much of your environment was just modified.

To make this topic too big, have any of you written an algorithm in a visual programming environment? For example A* or some rectangle packing algorithm.

Anyway, just curious if you know papers on why not lisp, why not smalltalk, why not VLPs, why not haskell, etc..

text: Why not lisp? IMO because there is nothing about Lisp that actually makes code easy to read and write (versus other common languages).

elements.text: Why not lisp? IMO because there is nothing about Lisp that actually makes code easy to read and write (versus other common languages).

text: Why not Smalltalk? Because I fundamentally disagree that OOP can lead to good code architecture.

elements.text: Why not Smalltalk? Because I fundamentally disagree that OOP can lead to good code architecture.

text: Yes, I've had the problem of ruining a Smalltalk and Lisp images.  A practical problem, not a fundamental one.  There's nothing preventing OS-type isolation or good checkpointing.  In practice, we would pass around images like most people pass around Word documents with all the attendant advantages and disadvantages.

elements.text: Yes, I've had the problem of ruining a Smalltalk and Lisp images.  A practical problem, not a fundamental one.  There's nothing preventing OS-type isolation or good checkpointing.  In practice, we would pass around images like most people pass around Word documents with all the attendant advantages and disadvantages.

text: Why not VLPs? Because that usually means "boxes and arrows", and there's nothing about that that makes programming inherently easier. On the contrary, it's often used to represent the same old code architectures but in a more verbose manner.

elements.text: Why not VLPs? Because that usually means "boxes and arrows", and there's nothing about that that makes programming inherently easier. On the contrary, it's often used to represent the same old code architectures but in a more verbose manner.

text: Why not Haskell? Because the academic community have made it unlearnable. It's a research artifact.

elements.text: Why not Haskell? Because the academic community have made it unlearnable. It's a research artifact.

text: <@UCGAK10LS> Started a thread.  Seems like the better way to carry on the topical conversation.  (I can't say I know how to use Slack.)

text: I don't personally mind where replies end up when channels aren't busy. Will reserve future responses for the thread.

elements.text: I don't personally mind where replies end up when channels aren't busy. Will reserve future responses for the thread.

text: It's also true that people, at least in the past, would customize their own Lisps rather than use other people's libraries.  Doesn't help that Common Lisp was everything except the kitchen sink so to speak.

elements.text: It's also true that people, at least in the past, would customize their own Lisps rather than use other people's libraries.  Doesn't help that Common Lisp was everything except the kitchen sink so to speak.

text: Starting threads just seems to be how we do things here.  Others may have an opinion for real.

elements.text: Starting threads just seems to be how we do things here.  Others may have an opinion for real.

text:
> Imaging running `stpm` (smalltalk package manager) and having no idea how much of your environment was just modified.

If we introduce strict versioning of all changes, then it gonna be less chaotic, more practical

elements.text: Imaging running
stpm
(smalltalk package manager) and having no idea how much of your environment was just modified.
If we introduce strict versioning of all changes, then it gonna be less chaotic, more practical

text: It's been a long, long time since I used Smalltalk much.  And then there was kind of a patch format that people would send around.  (This was before version control as we know it.)

elements.text: It's been a long, long time since I used Smalltalk much.  And then there was kind of a patch format that people would send around.  (This was before version control as we know it.)

text: The one lesson is that objects were more central than their code.  Adding a bunch of methods to a class was a not a big deal, but changing fields was because you might have old instances of that class.  Sometimes you'd get weird ad hoc versioning, a path to migrating old objects to the new format.  Lots of experiments.

elements.text: The one lesson is that objects were more central than their code.  Adding a bunch of methods to a class was a not a big deal, but changing fields was because you might have old instances of that class.  Sometimes you'd get weird ad hoc versioning, a path to migrating old objects to the new format.  Lots of experiments.

text:
> Smalltalk often mentions the entire environment is written in smalltalk and modifiable live. That sounds great for experimenting but horrible for every day use. Imaging running `stpm` (smalltalk package manager) and having no idea how much of your environment was just modified.

Here on Linux, I have no idea how much of my system is modified even when I run `apt` or any other package manager, for that matter :smile:.

text: But yes, a single global mutable live image doesn't sound great for everyday use. As others mentioned, it seems possible to add on isolation, versioning, snapshots, etc.

elements.text: But yes, a single global mutable live image doesn't sound great for everyday use. As others mentioned, it seems possible to add on isolation, versioning, snapshots, etc.

text:
I knew someone would bring that up. The difference is arguably one of culture. Culturally it's not normal for a language's package manager to modify your system but in many Smalltalk lectures it's considered a feature that the entire smalltalk stack is modifiable from anywhere which suggests that modifying it is encouraged vs say most language package managers where it's not encouraged.

it also seems like smalltalk is trying to monolithic. Make everything smalltalk and you all the benefits of smalltalk which is probably true but I think am happy with the present situation of lots of variety than in some alternate reality where smalltalk one and 100% of code is smalltalk because the entire system is smalltalk. Of course I don't know what I'm missing so I can't really compare that reality with the current one.

elements.text:

it also seems like smalltalk is trying to monolithic. Of course I don't know what I'm missing so I can't really compare that reality with the current one.

text: Images can work out surprisingly well.  My team's been doing it with Rails for 10+ years (in lieu of a ActiveRecord) and haven't been able to kick the habit yet.

elements.text: Images can work out surprisingly well.  My team's been doing it with Rails for 10+ years (in lieu of a ActiveRecord) and haven't been able to kick the habit yet.

text:
On a slight tangent, <@UC6997THT> this statement has me wondering which universe you inhabit:

> ..to use anything you have to understand it..

Isn't _all_ of modern software development based on using things without understanding them? I'm constantly feeling like a throwback for saying people should try to understand what they use, but this is the first time I've heard someone state it like it's a physical law.

Anyway, I can see where you're coming from in the rest of your comment, and Steve Yegge has written before about the different kinds of programmer personalities: <https://plus.google.com/u/0/110981030061712822816/posts/KaSKeg4vQtz>. But it's definitely not true that you have to understand a Lisp macro to be able to use it. Macros are often _easy_ to understand, and they reward curiosity. But understanding their internals is not mandatory.

. But it's definitely not true that you have to understand a Lisp macro to be able to use it. Macros are often
easy
to understand, and they reward curiosity. But understanding their internals is not mandatory.
